lines.text: The phone - Senator Munson.
Tell him I've gone out.
Why?
Because, Johnny, he'll want to do some things that might obligate me.
I mean why do you want me to lie? If you're in, you're in; if you're out, you're out.
Son, this is a Washington, D.C. kind of lie. It's when the other person knows you're lying, and also knows you *know* he knows. You follow?
Was that Brig? What's the matter?

[Hanging up phone]
He's dead.
Brig?
In his office. Cut his throat.

I'm an egghead. I'm not only an egghead, I'm a premeditated egghead. I set out to become an egghead and at this moment I'm in full flower of eggheadedness, and I hope to spread the spores of egghead everywhere I go.
Mr. President, with the chair's permission, I shall be very brief.
The chair gladly gives any senator permission to be brief.
Now, Mr. Gelman. You told me something about names in this comunist cell.

Yes. Nobody used their right names. Mr. Leffingwell was called Walker, Bukowski was called Fitzgerald. I never learn James Morton's real name. They tried to give me the name of Andrews. About that time I quit.
What happened when you quit?
Mr. Leffingwell failed me in his class of Government administration.
Why didn't you report all of this to the University authorities?
I was afraid.
And you're not afraid now?
Yes. I'm afraid. But I couldn't stand by and see a man like Mr. Leffingwell get into a position of such power of Secretary of State.
Can you corroborate this story, Mr. Gelman?
This man is an eyewitness, under oath, Mr. Chairman.

[shouting]
I'm not lying!
I didn't say you were lying.
Who're we gonna make peace with now? The Kickapoo Indians?
What I did was for the good of the country.
Fortunately, our country always manages to survive patriots like you.
[first lines]
[a boy is selling newspapers outside the U.S. Capitol, with the headline "Leffingwell Picked for Secretary of State"]

[to a customer]
Thank you.
Morning, son.

[taking change from Danta]
Good morning, senator... thank you.
[Danta gets into a taxicab]
He jumped the whale!
[last lines]
Senators. A great leader is dead. A bitter loss for our country. A bitter personal loss for all of us here. I move we adjurn out of respect until further notice.
So ordered!
Senator Anderson. Senator Van Ackerman is accusing the commitee of using smear tatics. Would you comment on this?
If Senator has any complaints to make he ought to write a letter to his congressman.
[all the reporters laugh]
Haven't had this much fun since the cayenne pepper hit the fan!
No, I don't know. He was good, and kind, and honest. I don't know what they were trying to use against him, but whatever it was, they can't use it anymore. So it doesn't matter, does it?
Do you have any idea who might be behind this?
No!
[sobbing]
N-no... excuse me... please excuse me...
Mr. President, is the Senator calling me a liar?
The record must stand as it is, Mr. President. How the Senator interprets that record is his own problem, not mine.
What do you think about that, you old buzzard?
Us old buzzards can see a mouse dying from 10,000 feet up. Us old buzzards have the sharpest eyes in creation. Right now I'm studyin' the terrain.

[to Brig about the President withdrawing Leffingwell]
He'll bend if he has to, and I guess he has to.

[with an air of desperation]
Call the press and announce your withdrawl and forget the President.
I've given the President my word.
Your word is not exactly coin of the realm.
No, maybe it isn't thanks to your committee, but I still place a value on it... and there's nothing more to be said.
[with finality]
Good night, Senator.
I guess I've been wrong in many many things. I don't suppose history will have much good to say of me. I can't dwell on that. I've done my best.
You're one of the great Presidents, Ross.
Well, if you think so, that's almost as good as History. Bye, Bobby.
Good night, Mr. President.
